p: There was an assumption supported by many researchers that while climatic factors may favor autochthonous transmission by increasing vector densities and accelerating the parasite development, the re-emergence of malaria in Europe (e.g. temperate regions) would hardly occur due to other counteractive factors, primarily the socioeconomic changes in land-use and agriculture practices, and effective functioning of the public health system [ 37, 39, 40, 41].
